repnme.cdata!:
Niger - Public Expenditure Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project are as
            follows: the project outcome is satisfactory, the
            project's sustainability is likely, the institutional
            development impact is modest, and the Bank and Borrower
            performance are both satisfactory. The implementation of the
            project points to several lessons, with implications for the
            design of subsequent adjustment operations for Niger. First,
            Government ownership of the reform program supported by the
            project was critical. Second, although commitment was
            necessary, it proved insufficient for full implementation of
            the reform program in the presence of limited capacity.
            Indeed, limited technical and managerial capacity
            constrained program implementation. Thus, capacity must be
            built to design and implement policies and programs in
            Niger. While this is being done, a pragmatic approach should
            consist of tailoring reforms to the country's
            institutional and technical capacity. Third, the
            project's design as a two-tranche operation and its
            timeframe facilitated the implementation of critical
            elements of the reform program, including privatization and
            procurement reform which require a longer implementation
            time and follow-up actions. Fourth, adjustment operations
            can be an effective tool to advance specific policy reforms
            in the social sectors.  Fifth, the lack of an efficient
            monitoring and evaluation system was a major weakness for
            the implementation of structural and social policy reforms
            under this project Sixth, the burden of adjustment
            operations in Niger must hinge on both expenditure
            management and revenue mobilization. Increasing the level of
            mobilization of domestic revenue through revenue-enhancing
            measures would complement expenditure reforms. It would also
            alleviate Niger's extreme dependence on unpredictable
            external aid. Seventh, the project has helped strengthen the
            prerequisites to programmatic lending by improving public
            finance management, transparency in budget execution and
            reporting. However, a key lesson that comes out is that much
            remains to be done to prepare Niger for programmatic
            lending. As noted in the current CAS, progress is needed in
            three critical areas before Niger is ready for consolidated
            programmatic lending: (i) gradual introduction of program
            budgeting on the basis of comprehensive sector strategies;
            (ii) a consolidation of fiduciary and budget management
            reforms; and (iii) intensified efforts to build
            institutional and individual capacity. Lessons drawn from
            this project's implementation have influenced the
            design of a subsequent public expenditure adjustment
            operation (PEAC II) both in its conceptual framework and its
            operational modalities.

docna.cdata!: Niger - Public Expenditure Adjustment Credit Project

repnme.cdata!:
Niger - Public Expenditure Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Expenditure Adjustment Credit
            Project, will provide financing to the Government's
            program of poverty reduction, and economic reform during
            2001-2002, while contributing to the consolidation of sound
            macroeconomic policies. It will continue to support the
            Government's budgetary management reform program, and
            its efforts to improve public expenditure allocations
            towards poverty reduction programs, and strategies, as well
            as support the ongoing implementation of key social sector,
            and structural reforms. By fostering macroeconomic, and
            financial stability, improving public resources management,
            and, addressing institutional development to improve public
            service delivery, the project will benefit, and help
            implement poverty reduction programs. Nonetheless, the
            project is of high risk, due to the country's
            political, and credibility constraints, in addition to weak
            administrative capacity, and uncertain growth, and
            macroeconomic stability.

docna.cdata!: Niger - Public Expenditure Adjustment Credit Project
